Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research Spatial Archaeometry: Integrating Spatial Analysis into Archaeological Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SPARC program promotes the use of spatial analysis, 3D modeling, aerial and geophysical remote sensing technologies in archaeological research projects around the world. The increasing availability and sophistication of these technologies and methods profoundly affects how archaeologists and other scholars work. The things archaeologists study - from artifacts to sites to landscapes - almost always have a spatial component and for many decades space has been viewed as one of the central dimensions of archaeological study. The capabilities of geospatial technologies to enhance the discovery and interpretation not only offers new data, but also creates entirely novel means of engaging with the archaeological record. Through the SPARC Program high-impact projects seeking to explore and implement geospatial technologies and methods are selected based on peer reviewed applications. Their work is supported through close collaborations with experts in spatial archaeometry at The University of Arkansas' Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies (CAST), the University of Glasgow and Dartmouth University. Together, the teams at these institutions form a center for innovative geospatial research and methods in archaeology. Technical experts and research staff at CAST, Dartmouth and Glasgow actively promote geospatial technologies in archaeology, and collaborate with the selected projects, providing access to equipment, methodological and domain expertise, and intensive training.

The Program's goals are to: enhance the research productivity of archaeological projects by making geospatial technologies available to researchers who would not otherwise have access to the tools or skills needed to collect and analyze these data; directly generate high value archaeological data by participating in fieldwork and analytical projects to efficiently collect and analyze geospatial data; provide training opportunities for students and professionals seeking to use geospatial techniques in their own research; promote the development of new geospatial methods and applications in archaeology and the visibility of these innovations in the broader archaeological community; and support good practice and promote innovation in archiving and publication of digital geospatial data. The new support from the NSF Archaeometry program will allow SPARC to continue building a program that is increasingly visible - attracting top research projects; efficient - as project staff build on their experience; high impact - as pilot projects build skills in research teams around the world; and innovative - with broader collaborations leading to significant methodological advancements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award, "Collaborative Research Spatial Archaeometry: Integrating Spatial Analysis into Archaeological Research", helped fund the Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations (SPARC) Program. SPARC is a collaboration between the Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies at the University of Arkansas, the Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations Laboratory at Dartmouth College, and the Department of Archaeology at the University of Glasgow. This Public Outcomes Report outlines activities for CAST and Glasgow.

SPARC's goals are to: 

  1. enhance the research productivity of archaeological projects by making geospatial technologies available to researchers who would not otherwise have access to the tools or skills needed to collect and analyze these data; 
  2. directly generate high value archaeological data by participating in fieldwork and analytical projects to efficiently collect and analyze geospatial data; 
  3. provide training opportunities for students and professionals seeking to use geospatial techniques in their own research; 
  4. promote the development of new geospatial methods and applications in archaeology and the visibility of these innovations in the broader archaeological community; and 
  5. support good practice and promote innovation in archiving and publication of digital geospatial data. 

Since 2013, SPARC has supported 37 projects involving 77 PIs (Principal Investigators) and co-PIs from 50 institutions, resulting in 28 publications, 29+ presentations, over $1.3 million in new grants, 9 websites, and free online educational materials. This 2018-2020 cycle of the SPARC Program supported 4 new projects for CAST/Glasgow:

  • Geophysical Investigations of 9th- to 14th-century AD Occupation Mounds in the Basanga Region of Western Zambia: Research at Mwanamaimpa, on precolonial African cities
  • Mapping Chacoan Roads in SE Utah, on 
  • All That Glitters: Spatial Archaeometric Approaches to Specularity
  • 3D GPR Survey at the Poverty Point World Heritage Site

 

Full descriptions of these projects and more general information about the SPARC Program, including research outcomes and their final reports, can be found at https://sparc.cast.uark.edu/. 

Intellectual Merit

SPARC focuses on spatial archaeometry: the application of scientific techniques to measure properties of archaeological materials at all spatial scales, from artifacts to features such as buildings, to whole archaeological sites and ancient landscapes. The things archaeologists study almost always have a spatial component and spatial analysis context, such as the site where they came from or the location within the site, is important to understand not just the date of an artifact, but also understand patterns of human behavior. Advances in software and equipment such as drones make the ability to acquire and analyze this data. For example, in this cycle, the Zambia SPARC project used near-surface geophysics to locate subsurface archaeological deposits without digging a hole. In another project, Cedar Mesa, SPARC analyzed a type of imagery called LiDAR to detect ancient Native American roads in the US SW. However, the high costs of instrumentation and software, combined with the expertise they require, create a hurdle for many archaeologists who aim to deploy geospatial technologies in research projects: access to technical skills, equipment and practitioners remains limited. The SPARC Program expands access to and the use of geospatial methods to US-based archaeologists for their research around the world.

Broader Impacts

The increasing availability and sophistication of geospatial technologies is not merely generating new data, but is facilitating entirely novel means of exploring the human past. Spatial archaeometric techniques can also save archaeologists (and taxpayers) money, through increasing the time and cost efficiency of where archaeological surveys and excavations take place. 

SPARC uses its research results to provide educational resources for archaeologists (and archaeology enthusiasts) to use. For example, in this cycle SPARC developed a lesson plan that explores an archived collection of 3D models from one of its past projects, "Boston Fingerprints". The "Boston Fingerprints" project involved ceramics which had visible handprints and fingerprints visible on the vessel surfaces that came from two historical 19th century sites used during the Revolutionary War: Parker-Harris Pottery Site and Three Cranes Tavern Site in Charlestown, Massachusetts. This lesson plan contain step-by-step guidance on how to use and analyze the archived 3D data using free software (https://github.com/castuofa/sparc_teaching). SPARC has been actively archiving project data in an open-source repository, Zenodo, for public access.

SPARC also communicates its results with the broader public. For example, the Poverty Point SPARC award provided RTK (real-time kinematic) GPS support for a 3D GPR (ground penetrating radar, a geophysical technique) survey at the Poverty Point World Heritage Site in Louisiana. Poverty Point consists of a vast, integrated complex of earthen monuments, constructed 3,700-3,100 years ago by hunter-fisher-gatherers. The Poverty Point project hosted an Open House for visitors to observe data collection in action and learn more about the project; several regional newspapers and the local TV station, KNOE Channel 8, ran stories. Other 2018-2020 outreach activities have included lectures for the National Museums of Zambia and the University of Zambia and online webinars for the Society for American Archaeology.
